title: Efficacy of Paper-based Cognitive Training in Vietnamese Patients With Early Alzheimer's Disease
description_brief: The purpose of this study is to assess the efficacy of paper-based cognitive training in Vietnamese patients with early Alzheimer's disease
explanation_target: Reason: The trial tests a non‑pharmacologic, paper‑based cognitive training program intended to improve cognition (memory, attention, language, executive function) in people with early Alzheimer’s disease — i.e., an intervention aimed at cognitive improvement rather than directly modifying amyloid/tau pathology or treating neuropsychiatric symptoms. citeturn0search3turn0search5

Act: Extracted details from public trial records — title: "Efficacy of Paper‑based Cognitive Training in Vietnamese Patients With Early Alzheimer's Disease" (ClinicalTrials ID NCT04949750). Intervention listed: Paper‑based cognitive training; Sponsor: University of Medicine and Pharmacy at Ho Chi Minh City; status and timeline details available in registries. No drug or biologic is used. citeturn0search3turn0search8

Reflect: Classification decision — fits the provided definition of 'Cognitive enhancer' (an intervention intended to improve cognitive function without targeting underlying AD pathology). This is not a biologic or small molecule and is not focused on neuropsychiatric symptom management or diagnostic testing, so 'cognitive enhancer' is the best category. Supporting evidence that paper‑based cognitive training can produce cognitive gains in early AD is shown in prior published studies of similar paper‑and‑pencil programs. citeturn0search2turn0search1

explanation_agent: Reason: The intervention is a non-pharmacologic, paper-based cognitive training program intended to improve cognition by engaging learning and practice-dependent brain changes (neuroplasticity) rather than modifying specific molecular AD pathologies (amyloid, tau, ApoE, etc.). This aligns conceptually with synaptic plasticity and neuroprotection mechanisms. citeturn0search0turn0search1

Act: Extracted trial details — title: "Efficacy of Paper-based Cognitive Training in Vietnamese Patients With Early Alzheimer's Disease" (ClinicalTrials ID NCT04949750). Intervention: Paper-based cognitive training (12-week program alongside standard care); no drug or biologic is used. Evidence that paper-and-pencil cognitive training can yield domain-specific cognitive improvements in early AD is reported in prior studies. citeturn0search0turn0search2turn0search1

Reflect: Classification check — the trial aims to enhance cognitive function through behavioral training and presumed neuroplastic mechanisms, so the best CADRO match is M) Synaptic Plasticity/Neuroprotection. It is not a molecular-targeted therapy (ruling out A–L, I, J, K, etc.), not explicitly multi-target pharmacology (R), and not a diagnostic or non-therapeutic study (T). If one preferred a conservative label for interventions without an explicit biological target, 'T) Other' could be argued, but given CADRO's scope, M is the most specific appropriate category. citeturn0search1turn0search0
